title: Effects of Transforming Inches to Centimeters
question_text:
Incoming freshmen at a large high school routinely have their heights measured by the school nurse. The nurse records each height in inches and then determines the standardized $z$-score for each student.
How would the $z$-scores be affected if each height was converted from inches to centimeters? NOTE: $1 \text{ inch} = 2.54\text{ cm}$

choices.text: The $z$-scores will all be multiplied by $2.54$.
All $z$-scores will be $254$% of their previous values.
There is no way to predict what will happen to the $z$-scores.

solution:
Changing the units of measure has no effect on $z$-scores. A $z$-score measures how many standard deviations an observation is above/below the mean.

The spread of heights around the mean is not affected by the fact that we may choose to use a different unit of measure. Therefore, $z$-scores for each student will remain unchanged.

Explanation of Distractors

Choice 'B' is incorrect. To convert inches to centimeters, we would multiply by $2.54$. Therefore, the mean that we determined by measuring in inches will be multiplied by $2.54$ when converting to cm. Likewise, the standard deviation that we determined by measuring in inches will be multiplied by $2.54$ when converting to cm. The $z$-score remains unchanged.

Choice 'C' is incorrect. The difference between $2.54$ (cm) and $1$ (inch) has nothing to do with the $z$-score.

Choice 'D' is incorrect. While the value describing an individual's height in cm is $254$% of the value that describes his/her height in inches, this does not mean that the new $z$-score will be $254$% of the original value.

Choice 'E' is incorrect. No prediction is necessary - just knowledge of the fact that z-scores are not affected by converting to a different unit of measure.
